## GAD-7 vs EDDS

The comparison between Generalised Anxiety Disorder Assessment (GAD-7) and Eating Disorder Diagnostic Scale (EDDS) offers a fascinating insight into how different psychological instruments measure varied aspects of mental health. GAD-7 provides a comprehensive assessment of generalised anxiety disorder while the EDDS gauges the severity of eating disorders. However, deciphering just how much these different questionnaires overlap can be daunting without the right tools. This is where Harmony steps in. Harmony provides an innovative approach to comparing and harmonising such questionnaires, transforming the GAD-7 vs EDDS task into a hassle-free experience. Harmony uses natural language processing and generative AI models to harmonise questionnaire items, bringing an unprecedented level of accuracy to the GAD-7 vs EDDS comparison. The software compares the two instruments and presents a percentage match between each item, sweeping aside the need for a time-consuming manual analysis. The GAD-7 vs EDDS comparison is made even more convenient by Harmony's intuitive user interface, which allows researchers to drag and drop their own instruments as PDFs. Delving into the differences and similarities between GAD-7 and EDDS is not just conducive to a broader understanding of mental health but is crucial for the effective interpretation of longitudinal studies. With Harmony, you can accelerate this research process by seamlessly harmonising the questionnaires. Therefore, in exploring the GAD-7 vs EDDS comparison, Harmony proves to be an invaluable tool in the hands of researchers and psychologists worldwide.

## Questions in GAD-7

|   No. | GAD-7 English                                                                                                                                      |
|------:|:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|     1 | Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge                                                                                                               |
|     2 | Not being able to stop or control worrying                                                                                                         |
|     3 | Worrying too much about different things                                                                                                           |
|     4 | Trouble relaxing                                                                                                                                   |
|     5 | Being so restless that it is hard to sit still                                                                                                     |
|     6 | Becoming easily annoyed or irritable                                                                                                               |
|     7 | Feeling afraid, as if something awful might happen                                                                                                 |
|     8 | If you checked any problems, how difficult have they made it for you to do your work, take care of things at home, or get along with other people? |
